title: Seascale Walks

images.title: Peter Eckersley / Seascale shoreline
images.caption: Seascale shoreline. The village became a popular seaside resort with the opening of the Furness Railway in the 1850s. Beyond can be seen the remaining Winscale pile stack, soon to be demolished, where the 1957 fire occurred.

images.title: Peter Eckersley / Seascale Jetty
images.caption: Seascale Jetty. Completed for the Millennium Celebration, with BNFL the benifactor, the jetty stands above the remains of its Victorian forerunner.

images.title: Dunes behind Drigg foreshore by Perry Dark, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Dunes behind Drigg foreshore

images.title: Beach at Drigg by Anne Burgess, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Beach at Drigg

images.title: Nigel Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The River Mite at low tide, Ravenglass.

images.title: Nigel Chadwick, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Ravenglass & Eskdale Railway Station, Ravenglass. A narrow gauge, preservation railway running on an old mineral line into Eskdale.

description: This Cumbrian village is located on the coast on the edge of the Lake District National Park. The village is a nice place for a walk with coastal trails and nature reserves to explore. It's also accessible by public transport with a train station on the Cumbrian Coast Line, which runs between Carlisle and Barrow-in-Furness. This walk from the village follows the Cumbria Coastal Way to the Drigg Beach Nature Reserve and then on to the neighbouring village of Ravenglass. The area is a great for wildlife with lots of wading birds to spot on the river estuaries. There's also the option of extending the walk in Ravenglass by visiting the splendid Muncaster Castle .

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just a few miles inland you'll find the neighbouring village of Gosforth. It's well worth a visit with a 17th century pub, a 12th century church and an ancient Viking cross to see. The circular walk from the village explores Blengdale and the River Bleng with some pleasant riverside paths and woodland trails through Blengale Forest.

display_address: South Parade, Seascale, Cumberland, England, CA20 1PZ, United Kingdom
